item.title: Latex together with matplotlib!
item.description:
Sometimes you need to label your plot with math expression or Greek letters and ASCII is not enough.
Everything you need is to add to your script 

from matplotlib import rc
rc('font',**{'family':'sans-serif','sans-serif':['Helvetica']})
## for Palatino and other serif fonts use:
#rc('font',**{'family':'serif','serif':['Palatino']))
rc('text', usetex=True)

and write you text label like 

label = r'theoretical $f(nu)$')

item.title: The "initial condition" saga
item.description:
If reading the previous posts on N-body simulations you have though that initial conditions are a little and easy task, you were wrong! And me with you!
The first things I have understood banging against them were:

  • Gadget requires initial conditions (ICs) generate by (for example) N-GenIC

  • N-GenIC requires an initial power spectrum from CMBFast that is no longer used

  • CMBeasy should substitute CMBFast but it doesn't, it only works for CMB anisotropies

  • CAMB should substitute CMBFast

  • the CAMB interface is terrible and not very documentated

item.title: Cosmological simulations #7: Limitations and some considerations
item.description:
Limitations

In the previous posts we encountered some of the limitations of cosmological
simulations. Let's review these in detail.
First, we can consider a simulation composed of a finite box in a bigger space but to represent a real system, this box shouldn't be isolated so we use the periodic boundary conditions (here). This means that all the space around the box is filled with images of the box itself: a particle that leaves the box from one side will come in
from the opposite side.
